verses.text: Blessed is the man whose mouth has not offended, and whose heart is not tormented by guilt.
verses.comment: The blessing of a clean conscience is emphasized here—compare with Psalm 32:2 and James 3:2 where restraint in speech is a mark of maturity and blessedness.

verses.text: Blessed is the one whose conscience does not accuse him, and who has not lost hope.
verses.comment: Linking an untroubled conscience with hope foreshadows the Christian concept that true peace comes from being reconciled with God (1 Peter 3:16).

verses.text: Riches are not fitting for a greedy person; and what use is money to someone who is tightfisted?
verses.comment: A warning that wealth is useless unless combined with generosity, anticipating Jesus’ teachings on stewardship and the dangers of greed.

verses.text: Whoever denies himself gathers up for others, and when he rests, his feast is for strangers.
verses.comment: This echoes Ecclesiastes (2:18) regarding the futility of storing up for others; Jesus’ parable of the rich fool in Luke 12:16–21 parallels this wisdom.

verses.text: Whoever is evil to himself, to whom will he be good? He will not take pleasure in his own riches.
verses.comment: Self-neglect is linked with the inability to do good for others, an idea echoed in Jesus' command to love your neighbor as yourself (Mark 12:31).

verses.text: No one is worse off than one who harms himself, and such a person’s wickedness is repaid.
verses.comment: This verse teaches a law of moral consequences: harming one's own body or soul brings judgment. The importance of self-care is in line with respecting the body as a temple (1 Cor. 6:19).

verses.text: If he does good, he does so in forgetfulness; and in the end, he reveals his evil.
verses.comment: A warning that good works without sincere intent are empty—a theme picked up by Jesus regarding hypocritical practice (Matthew 6:1–4).

verses.text: The eye is evil toward bread, and he is a miser at his table.
verses.comment: The 'evil eye' here signifies jealousy and stinginess (see Prov. 23:6). Generosity at the table is a sign of blessing, and sharing bread is later used as a sign of fellowship (Acts 2:46).

verses.text: My child, if you have anything, be good to yourself, and present worthy offerings to the Lord.
verses.comment: The call to self-care and offering to God connects the physical and spiritual, suggesting the importance of both stewardship and sacrificial worship.

verses.text: Do not deprive yourself of a happy day, and let not a share of the desired good pass you by.
verses.comment: Affirms the legitimacy of enjoyment under God’s law—see Ecclesiastes 9:7-9 for similar wisdom. Human flourishing is seen as harmonious with reverence for God.

verses.text: Give your soul contentment with what you have, and offer the Lord your firstfruits with a generous hand.
verses.comment: Offering one's first and best to God is a sign of faith and devotion—Prov. 3:9 is a direct parallel. This prefigures the later practice of bringing one’s firstfruits to worship.

verses.text: Remember, death does not delay, and the decree of the grave has not been shown to you.
verses.comment: A wisdom reminder of life's brevity. See Psalm 39:4: understanding one’s mortality leads to wisdom (cf. Heb. 9:27).

verses.text: Before you die, do good to your friend, and reach out and give as your hand can find.
verses.comment: Doing good before death echoes the Beatitudes and Jesus’ command to lay up treasures in heaven (cf. Matt. 6:19-20).

verses.text: Do not withhold your wealth from yourself, for there is no pleasure in death, and you cannot take any of your riches there.
verses.comment: The ephemeral nature of wealth is underscored (Eccl. 5:15); compares to Jesus' teachings that treasures on earth perish.

verses.text: Leave your inheritance to your children and relatives.
verses.comment: Supporting the importance of family legacy; a good person provides for future generations.

verses.text: Let not your mind dwell anxiously on your wealth; for wealth was made for you, not you for wealth.
verses.comment: A subtle teaching of detachment from material possessions. See 1 Tim. 6:17—'God...gives us richly all things to enjoy.'

verses.text: How generously you will spend your money! It will go with you only as far as the grave.
verses.comment: Echoes the vanity of storing up wealth (Ps. 49:17). True treasure is found in generosity and eternal reward (Matt. 6:20).

verses.text: When you open your hands, give freely; as your hands open, so will God's hands be open to you.
verses.comment: Divine generosity parallels human generosity; see Luke 6:38—'With the measure you use, it will be measured to you.'

verses.text: My child, give and take, invest in yourself, for in the grave there is no enjoyment.
verses.comment: Making the most of life before the grave—see Ecclesiastes 9:10, a call to active living for God.

verses.text: All people grow old like a garment; a covenant ages like the result of many waters.
verses.comment: The imagery of aging refers to the fleeting nature of human life and the old covenant's fading, pointing to the need for renewal in Christ (Heb. 8:13).

verses.text: Blessed is the person who meditates on wisdom and ponders with understanding.
verses.comment: Blessedness comes from a life immersed in divine wisdom, paralleling Psalm 1:1-2. 'Meditation' here prefigures the spiritual practice of pondering God’s truth daily.

verses.text: She will pursue wisdom like a hunter, and lie in wait on her paths;
verses.comment: The active pursuit of wisdom is praised, aligned with Jesus’ call to seek first the kingdom (Matt. 6:33). Wisdom here is highly personified, a theme developed in Proverbs.

verses.text: He who peers through her windows and listens at her doors;
verses.comment: The metaphor of longing for wisdom, standing at her door, appears also in Proverbs 8:34 (‘Blessed is the one who listens to me, watching daily at my doors.’).

verses.text: Who lodges close to her house and fastens his tent peg near her walls;
verses.comment: Dwelling near wisdom echoes the longing for God's presence (Ps. 84:10). Persisting near wisdom's ‘house’ suggests constancy in seeking truth, reminiscent of abiding in Christ (John 15:4).

verses.text: Who sets up his tent near her, and lodges in a good place;
verses.comment: Staying in wisdom's presence recalls David's yearning to dwell in the house of the Lord (Ps. 27:4). It hints at the importance of both personal encounter and spiritual community.

verses.text: He will set his children under her shelter, and will lodge under her branches;
verses.comment: Wisdom offers protection and legacy—even children benefit. Parallels to the tree imagery in Prov. 3:18 for wisdom; similar to Jesus’ parable of the mustard seed (Matt. 13:32) where all find shelter.

verses.text: He will be sheltered by wisdom from the heat, and he will dwell in her glory.
verses.comment: Wisdom's protection is likened to a canopy in Isaiah 4:6 and Jeremiah 17:7-8—spiritually, this foreshadows abiding in Christ, who is true wisdom and provides ultimate security and glory (cf. 1 Cor. 1:30).
